blocks.name: prodf
blocks.content: An infinite product of complex terms is a function from an upper set of integers to ` CC ` . (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 4-Dec-2017.)
blocks.origin:
thm prodf(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wf(cseq(c0, cmul, c1), c2, cc))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cuz, c0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cz))
  -| wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c2)), wcel(cfv(c1, cv(s0)), cc))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
} = {
  seqf(s0, hs0, c0, cmul, c1, c2, cc, w0)
  adantl(w0, wa(wcel(cv(s0), cc), wcel(cv(hs0), cc)), wcel(co(cv(s0), cmul, cv(hs0)), cc))
  mulcl(cv(s0), cv(hs0))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.cmul.s(s0)
  diff.cc.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cmul)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm prodf(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(seq(c0(×, c1)): c2 → ℂ))
  ⊣ c2 =(ℤ≥ ` c0)
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 ∈ ℤ)
  ⊣ ((w0 ∧ s0 ∈ c2)→(c1 ` s0)∈ ℂ)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
  ⊣ d(s0, w0)
} = {
  seqf(s0, hs0, c0, cmul, c1, c2, cc, w0)
  adantl(w0, (s0 ∈ ℂ ∧ hs0 ∈ ℂ), (s0[×]hs0)∈ ℂ)
  mulcl(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
  diff.cmul.s(s0)
  diff.cc.s(s0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cmul)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(cc)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
}
